prompts: I have a job interview in two days and my anxiety spikes with sweaty palms and a racing heart during interviews. Can you give me a brief, step-by-step 10-minute pre-interview routine (breathing, grounding, and self-talk) plus 3 quick in-the-moment tricks I can use if I freeze?

On the subway I sometimes get sudden waves of anxiety that feel like a panic attack, and I don’t want to draw attention to myself. What are a few discreet techniques (a simple breathing pattern, a grounding-with-senses method, and a short mental script) I can use to ride it out in about 5 minutes?

I’ve been dealing with low mood and zero motivation lately (I work 9–5 and feel wiped in the evenings). Can you propose a simple one-week self-help plan with small, low-energy actions (10–20 minutes each) that include things like gentle movement, sunlight, basic journaling, and a quick wind-down for sleep? Please keep it budget-friendly and realistic for after work.

I get stuck in negative thought spirals like “I’m failing at everything.” Could you give me a short CBT-style thought-challenging worksheet I can use in 5–10 minutes, and show a filled-out example using that exact thought?

I’ve got 10 minutes between meetings and feel tense. Can you guide me through a quick breathing and muscle relaxation routine I can do at my desk without anyone noticing? Please keep it to 10 steps or less.

I’m having trouble winding down at night after late screen time. In 5-8 sentences, give me a simple pre-bed routine and a short visualization to quiet racing thoughts. I have no equipment and share a small apartment.

I think I'm having a panic attack—my chest is tight and my hands are tingling. Please talk me through a brief grounding routine right now using 4-7-8 breathing and the 5-4-3-2-1 senses method. Keep the steps simple, calm, and in short sentences.

Create a pocket-sized grounding checklist for panic attacks that I can screenshot. Include: one breathing pattern, one quick sensory grounding sequence, and a reassuring self-talk line. Use brief bullet points, 100 words max.

I’ve got a work networking mixer tonight and social anxiety tends to make me overheated and blank out. Could you give me a simple game plan: what to do in the first 5 minutes after I arrive, three low-pressure conversation starters, a polite way to exit a chat, and one quick grounding exercise if I start to panic?

Phone calls spike my anxiety, so I keep avoiding them. I need to call my dentist to reschedule an appointment. Can you provide a short script I can read, three tips to manage nerves during the call, and one tiny exposure step I can try tomorrow to make this easier?

Falling asleep takes me 60–90 minutes most nights, then I wake at 4 a.m. and can’t get back to sleep. I’m 38, generally healthy. I have 2 coffees before noon, scroll my phone in bed, and run at 8 p.m. three times a week. My bedroom is a bit bright from streetlights. Can you give me a brief, practical plan (no more than 8 bullet points) to improve this over the next 2 weeks, including what to do if I’m awake in the middle of the night?

Night shift help: I work 7 p.m.–7 a.m. three nights in a row, then have four days off. I keep flipping my schedule and feel exhausted and wired. What’s a simple schedule for sleep, light, caffeine, and naps I can follow on (1) the day of a first night shift, (2) between consecutive night shifts, and (3) the first day off? Please keep it concise and realistic.

Three months ago my younger brother died suddenly in a car crash. I'm back at work but some days I feel numb and other days I get hit with waves of anger and guilt. Can you give me 3–4 practical coping tips I can use during the workday, and a short boundary-setting script I can use when coworkers ask for details I don't want to share?

Our 12-year-old Labrador was euthanized last week. My 9-year-old has been crying at bedtime and asking, 'Where did Buddy go?' We've made a small memory box already. Could you suggest a gentle, age-appropriate way to explain death to them, plus a simple 5-minute bedtime ritual we can do for the next week?

I was broken up with last night after an 18-month relationship and I feel panicky and keep wanting to check their Instagram. Can you give me a simple 48-hour game plan (small, doable steps), plus one or two quick grounding/breathing techniques, and guidance on what to do about social media right now?

We ended a 5-year relationship amicably, share a lot of mutual friends, and still need to swap a few belongings. Please draft a brief, kind text to arrange a quick drop-off that sets clear boundaries and doesn’t invite a long conversation. Also share 3 concise tips for handling mutual friends without fueling gossip.

I keep second-guessing myself in meetings and end up staying quiet. Can you give me 4 practical, evidence-based strategies to speak up with confidence, plus one 30-second calming technique I can use right before I talk? Keep it concise.

I struggle with harsh self-talk. Please rewrite these thoughts into realistic, compassionate reframes, and pair each with one tiny action I can take today: 1) "I'm not good enough." 2) "I always mess things up." 3) "People will think I'm stupid." 4) "If I fail, it's over." Keep it brief.

When a coworker talks over me in meetings, I feel my face get hot and I either shut down or snap. Can you give me 3 quick in-the-moment anger management techniques I can use (each under 30 seconds), plus a calm sentence I can say to reclaim the floor without sounding hostile?

I get irritated fast at home when my teen ignores chores, and I want a simple plan. Please outline a short 4-step anger management routine I can follow (pause, label, regulate, respond) and include a 60-second breathing/grounding script I can read aloud to myself.

I'm spiraling with anxiety about a presentation in an hour. Please give me: a 2-minute paced breathing plan (with counts), a 60-second grounding exercise, and three brief self-talk lines I can repeat.
After a tense argument, I keep ruminating and feel on edge. Can you give me a short DBT STOP skill script (one sentence per step), plus a one-paragraph self-compassion statement I can read to myself?

I'm about to walk into a high-stakes job interview and I'm jittery. Can you guide me through a discreet 2-minute breathing routine I can do while sitting in the lobby, plus a short grounding cue I can repeat silently?

At night my mind races with what-ifs. Please give me a simple 5-minute mindfulness practice I can do while lying in bed that combines breathing and a light body scan, with numbered steps and a gentle phrase to use on each exhale.

Help me challenge a recurring thought using CBT. Thought: "If I make one mistake at work, everyone will think I'm incompetent and I'll get fired." Context: I missed a small typo in a client email last week and my manager asked me to be more careful. Please identify possible cognitive distortions, ask 3 Socratic questions, and suggest a more balanced alternative thought.

Can you walk me through a quick CBT thought record? Situation: My friend didn't reply to my text for two days. Automatic thought: "They must be mad at me and don't want to hang out anymore." Emotions (0–100): Anxiety 70, Sadness 40. Help me list evidence for and against the thought, propose a more balanced thought, and suggest one small action I can take.

Here are three recurring negative thoughts I have: 'I'm terrible at my job,' 'People only tolerate me,' and 'If I can't do it perfectly, it's not worth trying.' Could you: 1) name the likely cognitive distortions in each, and 2) give me one realistic, kinder reframe for each that I can practice?

When I make a small mistake—like sending an email with a typo—my inner voice jumps to 'You always screw things up.' Could you write a brief self-talk script (2–3 sentences) I can use in the moment, plus a quick 60-second routine to help me stop the spiral?
I keep replaying an awkward conversation I had with my boss yesterday and it's making me anxious. Can you guide me through a simple 5-minute exercise right now to interrupt the rumination loop?

At night I get stuck in 'what if' worries about my health and money. Please give me 3 quick techniques to reduce worry (e.g., thought labeling, scheduled worry time, grounding), each with a one-sentence instruction and a one-line example.

I'm procrastinating on finishing a 10-slide client deck because of perfectionism. My inner critic keeps saying: 'If it's not flawless, they'll think I'm incompetent.' Please give me: - a short, 5-item 'good enough' checklist for this deck, - three self-compassionate reminders to quiet that voice, - a one-line send-off mantra I can say before I hit send. Keep it brief.

Yesterday I made a small mistake at work (typo in an email), and I've been stuck in self-criticism all day. Can you help me reframe these thoughts using a compact CBT-style format (Automatic thought -> evidence for -> evidence against -> balanced thought)? Thoughts: 1) 'One mistake proves I'm careless.' 2) 'People will think less of me now.' 3) 'I have to be perfect to keep my job.' Please keep each line under 25 words.

I’ve been avoiding starting my 1,500-word research essay on urban heat islands, due in 3 days. I keep cleaning my apartment instead. Here’s what I have so far: topic: how tree canopy affects neighborhood temperatures; sources: Smith 2022 (trees reduce heat by 2–4 C), Lee 2020 (inequitable canopy cover), CityReport 2023 (local canopy map). Can you give me: 1) a 25-minute 'first bite' plan broken into 5-minute blocks; 2) a 2–3 sentence intro I can paste and start from; and 3) one simple rule to keep me from switching to chores?

I keep putting off calling my credit card company to set up a payment plan and it's stressing me out. Please write a short call script (greeting, what to say, how to ask for hardship options), plus a 10-minute prep checklist so I actually make the call right after reading this.

Help me set achievable goals to get back into consistent exercise. Context: I'm 29 with an office job, currently sedentary, about 10 extra lbs, mild knee pain, access to a gym, and only 30 minutes/day max in the mornings, Mon–Fri. Please: 1) propose a 4-week SMART goal, 2) outline a simple weekly plan, and 3) give 3 motivation tips for when I want to skip.

I'm preparing to change careers from marketing to data analytics over the next 6 months while working full-time. I can commit ~7 hours/week and have basic Excel skills. Create a concise roadmap with monthly milestones, two measurable KPIs to track progress, and a short self-talk script I can use to stay motivated when I'm stuck.

My manager often messages me after hours and expects quick responses. I don’t want to be rude, but I need to set a clear boundary around my availability. Can you give me a concise message I can send to set expectations, plus a short Slack status line I can use?

My neighbor frequently stops by without texting first, and it interrupts my work-from-home schedule. Can you write a polite but firm script I can use in person, and a short version I can send by text to ask them to check before coming over?

My boyfriend and I keep having the same fight about household chores. I feel resentful and he feels criticized. We both work full-time and want to handle this better. Can you suggest a simple, step-by-step script for a 15-minute check-in that helps us divide tasks fairly without blame? Please include 2–3 sample “I” statements I can use and 3 ground rules for the conversation.

I tend to go quiet when I’m overwhelmed in an argument, and my wife experiences it as stonewalling. I want to communicate what I need in those moments without making her feel shut out. Could you help me draft a short message (4–6 sentences) that sets a boundary, validates her feelings, and proposes a specific time to revisit the conversation?

I need help wording a conversation with my boyfriend about money boundaries. We’ve been together 3 years and live together. This month he used our joint account to buy a gaming PC without telling me, which made rent tight; he says he’ll “make it up next month.” I don’t want to attack him, but I need a clear agreement about joint vs. personal expenses and a way to bring it up tonight without it becoming a fight. Can you give me a concise script (3–5 sentences) using I-statements that (1) explains how I felt, (2) asks for a specific change, and (3) invites his perspective? Please also suggest one compromise to propose.

After a fight with my wife about visiting her family for the holidays, we haven’t spoken much in two days. I snapped and said I was “done with her family drama,” which hurt her feelings; she tends to shut down when criticized. I want to repair and restart the conversation without minimizing my needs. Can you draft a short apology plus a 4-step plan for how to discuss the holiday plan collaboratively (including a time-out signal if it gets heated)? Keep it brief and practical.

I'm the only child living near my mom (68) with early-stage Alzheimer's. I manage her meds, appointments, and finances while working full-time. My older brother lives 1,000 miles away and often texts criticism but rarely offers concrete help. I want to set boundaries and ask for specific support without starting a fight. Can you draft a short message (under 150 words) that is calm, appreciative, and non-accusatory, that: 1) clearly states what I'm handling and my limits; 2) offers three concrete ways he can contribute remotely (e.g., handling insurance paperwork, arranging grocery delivery, coordinating a monthly bill review); and 3) proposes a monthly 30-minute check-in call? Keep it warm but firm.

Caregiving has strained my marriage. Our 7-year-old has a chronic condition requiring nightly treatments; I carry most of the routine, and when I'm exhausted I get snappy, then my partner shuts down and says I make them feel useless. I want to reset the tone at home. Could you give me: (a) a 3–4 sentence script I can use tonight to acknowledge my snappiness, ask for teamwork, and propose one small task my partner can own; (b) a simple 20-minute nightly routine we can share that includes one micro-break for each of us; and (c) two boundary phrases I can use with my parents when they offer last-minute “advice” that adds stress? Please keep it concise.

I'm a single mom of a 3-year-old and an 8-month-old. Dinner time is chaos: the toddler throws food, the baby starts crying, and I end up snapping and then feel awful. I only have about 10 minutes before dinner to prepare myself. Can you give me a quick routine to stay calm, plus 3 short phrases I can use during the meltdown that set limits without yelling?

My 15-year-old and I keep getting into arguments about screens at night. I get stressed and say things I regret, and he shuts down. Can you give me a simple 3-step plan to de-escalate in the moment, a calm way to set a firm boundary about devices after 9 pm, and 3 sentence starters that keep the conversation respectful?

I'm a product manager at a mid-size tech company. For the last two months I've been constantly context-switching between back-to-back Zooms, 200+ Slack messages/day, and late-night doc reviews. I'm drained and short-tempered, and my focus is shot. Can you give me 3 concrete actions I can take this week to reduce stress and reclaim some focus, plus a short (3–4 sentence) note I can post to my team to set better communication boundaries?

I'm an ER nurse on rotating day/night shifts and I'm starting to feel burned out—emotional exhaustion, dread before shifts, and trouble sleeping after nights. I can't take a long vacation right now. What are a few evidence-based strategies I can use immediately to protect my energy on shift and a simple 15–20 minute wind-down routine for after night shifts? Also, suggest two points I can raise with my supervisor to adjust my schedule without sounding like I'm not a team player.

I’m a junior software engineer and every time I have a code review I feel like a fraud who’s about to be exposed. Can you give me: (1) a 60‑second pep talk I can read before reviews, (2) a 4‑item checklist to prep so I feel grounded, and (3) one sentence I can say when I don’t know an answer but will follow up? Keep it concise.

I’m a first‑year PhD student and keep thinking I only got in by mistake. I compare myself to others and avoid asking questions in seminar. Please give me: a brief cognitive reframe for the thought 'I tricked the admissions committee,' a daily 5‑minute exercise to collect evidence of competence, and 3 low‑stakes ways to ask clarifying questions without sounding dumb. Keep the reply under 180 words.

I’ve been struggling with how my body looks after having a baby, especially when I scroll social media and compare myself to others. Can you give me 5 practical, low-pressure ways to practice self-acceptance over the next month, plus a short daily affirmation I can repeat?

When I try on clothes, I fixate on flaws and leave feeling worse. Can you give me a quick, simple checklist to shift into a body-neutral mindset while shopping, and a two-sentence pep talk I can screenshot?

I’ve had rheumatoid arthritis for 8 years and I keep feeling angry at my body, then guilty when I cancel plans during flare-ups. I worry friends think I’m unreliable. Can you give me 3 practical ways to cope with that guilt, a simple 60-second grounding exercise for when I start spiraling, and a one-sentence text I can send to set a boundary kindly?

Since being diagnosed with long COVID, I’m grieving the ‘old me’ and mornings feel especially heavy. Please give me: (1) a short daily affirmation I can say to myself, (2) a simple 3-step emotional check-in routine that takes under 5 minutes, and (3) one idea for reconnecting with a hobby in a way that respects my new limits.

A loud noise at the office brought up a flashback from a past car accident. I’m shaky, floaty, and my hands are tingling with some tunnel vision. I’ve got 5 minutes before a meeting and need discreet grounding I can do at my desk without drawing attention (no scents, no apps). Can you give me a short, step-by-step script (60–90 seconds) to orient to the present, plus one simple sensory tool I can use with items on my desk?

I just woke from a trauma nightmare (past assault), heart pounding and shaky, and it’s 3 a.m. with roommates asleep. I need a quiet, gentle stabilization routine I can do in bed to help me feel safe and fall back asleep. Please walk me through a 2-minute, trauma-informed sequence focusing on slow breathing, orienting to the room, and a light self-soothing touch (like the butterfly hug), kept very simple and calm.

I keep getting intrusive thoughts about blurting out something offensive in work meetings. I never act on them, but they spike my anxiety and make it hard to focus. Can you give me 3–5 quick, practical strategies I can use in the moment to defuse the thought without doing mental rituals? Short steps or phrases are fine.

At night I sometimes get sudden images of my family getting into a car crash, and my heart races. I know these are intrusive thoughts, not intentions. Can you explain briefly how to label and accept intrusive thoughts, and share a simple 2-minute breathing or grounding exercise I can use when it happens?

I get a spike of jealousy when my boyfriend likes other women’s photos on Instagram, even though he’s never given me a real reason to worry. How can I manage that feeling in the moment and bring it up without sounding accusatory? Please give me 2–3 quick coping steps, a grounding technique I can do in under a minute, and a couple of example phrases I could use to talk to him about it.

Lately I’ve been feeling insecure at work when my teammates get praised and I don’t. I start comparing myself and spiral into “I’m not good enough.” Can you give me three simple cognitive reframes I can practice, a short 60-second routine to reset when the jealousy hits, and one boundary I can set with myself to reduce comparison?

I just moved to Portland for grad school and don’t know anyone. I’m introverted but enjoy indie films and weekend hikes. What are three realistic ways I can meet people this month that don’t involve bars, and could you draft a 2–3 sentence DM I can send to introduce myself in a local hiking group?

I’ve been feeling lonely working from home. Can you give me a simple 7-day plan with one small action each day (5–10 minutes) to increase social connection, and 3 friendly openers I can use when I bump into neighbors in the hallway?

Tonight I’m feeling overwhelmed and worried I might hurt myself. I’m in Denver, Colorado, alone, and there’s alcohol and a bottle of pills in my apartment. Can you help me make a short, step-by-step safety plan just for the next 24 hours? Please include: (1) warning signs to watch for, (2) 3–5 coping strategies I can do at home right now, (3) ways to make my space safer this evening, and (4) who I can reach out to, with U.S. crisis hotlines that offer call, text, and chat.

Can you help me create a discreet safety plan for leaving an abusive partner? I’m in Manchester, UK, with two children. I need a brief checklist for preparing to leave (key documents, money, code word with a friend, tech/phone safety, safe places), tips to stay safer if I can’t leave immediately, and a couple of UK helplines or services I can call or text. Keep it concise.
